lines.text: Eric Bates will delighted to meet you! The gentleman would be too, his name is Jack Brown. Jack! Master Bates!
HA HA! MAST!

[Talking to stuffed animals]
You know why there's a party downstairs? Do you fellas? Because it's goodbye for you guys. They're not gonna sell you anymore. They got a new toy to sell. It's called a Jack Brown. Me. The wind up asshole. And I'm gonna take over all the stores of America next Christmas. All the kids will be hollering for me. They're not gonna want no teddy bears like you. No they won't and they won't want no sad pandas and no tigers or leopards or lions or dumb rabbits. The kids will want a Jack Brown Wind Up. "Mommy I want a Jack Brown Wind-up! Susie has one that can play basketball! And Otto has one that can drive a Cadillac, and he's real cute too and I wanna pinch his nose!" I've sold out to Moorehouse, you know. My life is over. I'm gonna wind up in this room with all you toys for the rest of my life.
Angela! Jesus H. Christ!
Is that her full name?
I'm writing a book. Writing a book is a job.
No, writing a book is a copout.
Hang on, I got the key.
You got the key? Why didn't you say so?
You didn't ask me.
What do you do with... your thing?
Is this a hypothetical question or is there a lady involved?
Eric bought a black man.
I wasn't aware that we sold them.
Take your pants down
Sir?
Take your pants down.
[Morehouse pulls his pants down]
That's power.
Do you have a license to drive a car down the steps?
Come back here, the game's not over.
I don't feel like playing anymore.
Are you upset because I was winning? You hate to lose?
I just don't wanna play anymore.
What if I tell your father?
He won't care.
Your father doesn't care that his son is a quitter?
He doesn't care what I am, so long as I stay out of his way.

[Jack Brown is dressed as a waitress]
You're pretty strong for a little lady and you have a lot of hair on your lip. We don't like our waitresses to have hairy lips. So I'll tell you what, shave. Oh, and after you shave, you're fired.
I gotta pull up my boots real high because the bullshit is getting thicker.
No. No tomorrow. No next week. No next month. No next year.
I know what I want.
He wants the Wonder Wheel,
[he and other business men get into a huddle]
The black man!
He wants one in black, so all we do is...
The black *man*!
He wants the black man. Huh? Oh no. No. No tomorrow. No next week. No next month. No next year.
For that kind of money, if Eric blows his nose, you wipe it.
C'Mon, Wizard, I'm gonna send you back to the land of Oz.
Are you crazy?
Yes, but trust me!
Why me? Of all the stuff in the store, why did you pick me?
You made me laugh. I wanted a friend who made me laugh.
So of all the toys in the store you wanted a friend. If you want a friend, you don't buy a friend, Eric, you earn a friend through love and trust and respect.
Come see my train!
You're not listening to me, Eric, you don't order your friends around, you ask them.
Oh. You wanna come see my train, friend?
No.
[They hug]

[Happily]
I'm gonna kill you.
I love you, Jack.
For 18 months I've been trying to get a job on your newspaper, but the only black people you hire do windows, mop floors and kiss ass. I don't like it, I've tried it.
I only get Eric for a week each year.
Then you should get better lawyers, you shouldn't have to have him that long.
It just so happens I love him.
Frankly, Scarlet, I don't give a damn.
I want Eric to understand that having money means never having to say you're sorry.
I think that's about all the kid understands.
Was I bad?
Were you bad? What you were gave a new meaning to the word 'bad'!
The truth has nothing to do with reality. You have to deal with reality. In reality, any one of these people, with a little persuasion, will say what I want them to say, because I am reality.
Two-seven.
Two-five.
Three thousand dollars.
I wonder if Eric knows what kind of a bastard he's getting.
We're looking for a part-time woman.
I can be a part-time woman.
I'm clean, but that's more than the floor is. You know what is on that floor?
What?
Your dinner.
These democrats don't normally support us.
Now, Senator, we agreed to keep that under our hats. If they knew this was a fund raiser, we'd be all alone.
What do you think, Mr. O'Brien?
Forget you know me.
Why is it always my toy department? Why can't the kid grow up and get interested in stereos?
I'm hoping to get him interested in something we don't even sell.
We sell everything.
Tim O'Brien, toys.
Jack Brown, windows.
Up yours, you mother.
I'm gonna tell your father!
Does everybody around here say that?
Yeah.
Well I'm not gonna say it anymore.
That's Fancy Bates.
His daughter?
His wife. Numero three.
You think she's ready?
Ready for what?
The black experience. You ready?
It's that bad out there?

[after U.S. Bates made him drop his pants in front of everybody]
Worse.
Fair-weather friend bastard.
Who are we gonna tell God? We are gonna say "Hey God! life's unfair!" You know what he's gonna say "Tough Titties!"
Heaven forbid, you just tell him no, you ass.
That's U.S., not you ass.
